Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Coalescence-based Inference of Adaptation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop a mathematical framework for investigating genomic sequences that respond differently to local environmental stresses. This framework will compare mutation patterns from samples taken at different locations to estimate possible genealogies of these samples; these genealogies will be used to estimate the parameters of a number of population genetic models. These parameters will be able to tell us about potential selection differences among geographical locations. This new mathematically rigorous framework has the promise to supersede current ad hoc and inadequate summary statistics. Potential applications of this framework include improving interventions for diseases (e.g. individualized responses for HIV patients), and improving our understanding of which gene regions are responsible for long-term survival in harsh environments. The framework will be publicly available in standalone computer software that can be run on small computers or large computing clusters. This research draws from multiple science and technology disciplines (biology, computational science, and statistics) and thus will provide a great basis on which to mentor undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students and foster their interest towards a field that desperately needs more training opportunities.

The building blocks for this framework are rooted in coalescence theory, a branch of theoretical population genetics discussing the shapes of genealogies of individuals, and Bayesian statistics evaluating different scenarios and integrating over possible solutions using Markov chain Monte Carlo technology. The data will be genomic sequences which are known to contain technical errors; to successfully differentiate among gene regions that are under selection for particular environments, these errors must be taken into account, but currently are not. Additionally, samples from different geographical locations (for example different patients, different islands, or different habitats) can be grouped in different ways, which requires that the framework be capable of delivering optimality criteria that help to order different scenarios. Progress and the final work will be documented on the websites http://popgen.sc.fsu.edu and http://peterbeerli.com.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated the development of new mathematical and computational methods to investigate potential adaptation to different environments. Random mutations may affect the performance of the bearer of these mutations. Suppose the mutation allows using the resources of a particular environment better. In that case, the bearer of the mutation may have more offspring than others. A hypothetical genealogy links individuals in a population. When mutations have no negative or positive effect, the splitting times on this genealogy follow the well-established Kingman coalescent. Variants of Kingman's coalescent can model deviations of this neutral expectation. Exploring such a variant allowed a new, general description of the coalescence process of which Kingman's coalescence is a special case. This new variant was described in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences as 'The fractional coalescent' because its derivation depends heavily on the mathematical field of fractional calculus. The method is available in a computer program. 

These population genealogies are estimated using the differences in DNA sequences extracted from multiple individuals in a population. The parallel sequencing techniques used today allow generating large amounts of data. However, these techniques are not error-free and affect the analysis. Currently, very few analysis methods use these errors to correct their estimates. Modern sequencing machines usually deliver a sequence and a quality score?incorporating the quality score into the analysis succeeded in a test software setting. But the incorporation is not fully implemented in the distributed software yet. The next version of the software, distributed in Spring 2022, will include a quality score data input section. 

A fundamental problem with software for inference of population parameters from sequence data is the dependency on specific population genetics models. Comparison of the statistical power of different models is often difficult. The software MIGRATE implements two different methods: (1) Model comparison based on Bayes factors [BF] and (2) Model comparison using the "Reversible Jump" [RJ] method. BF essentially compares the total probability of a particular model to another using the integrated likelihoods of the parameter of the models. Reversible jump (RJ) runs all models in the same analysis. The duration of how often the system stays in one particular model compared to the others measures the support for a model. RJ works well when the models have very similar qualities. However, if one model is considerably worse than others, this model will not be explored at all. As a result, one cannot get a probability for this flawed model at all. In contrast, the BF method runs each model independently. It then compares the likelihoods giving each model the same chance of exploration. The BF method is easier to use than the RJ method and delivers more consistent results than the RJ method.The software developed in this research is available as open-source software.
